choices.D: To support seamless MPLS, TDP must be used as the label protocol.
choices.C: If each area is running its own IGP, the ABR routers must redistribute the IGP routing table into BGP.
choices.A: To support seamless MPLS, the BGP route reflector feature must be disabled.
choices.B: If each area is running its own IGP, BGP must provide an end-to-end MPLS LSP.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct. The whole purpose of seamless MPLS or unified MPLS is to segment the network into multiple isolated IGPs and establish LSPs through the use of MP-BGP only between the loopback interfaces of the PE routers.

Selected Answer: B
B - it is explained in this link

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst9600/software/release/16-12/configuration_guide/mpls/b_1612_mpls_9600_cg/configuring_seamless_mpls.html

New Link
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst9600/software/release/16-12/configuration_guide/mpls/b_1612_mpls_9600_cg/multiprotocol_label___switching__mpls_.html

New Link:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst9600/software/release/16-12/configuration_guide/mpls/b_1612_mpls_9600_cg/configuring_seamless_mpls.html

100% Correct Answer is A 
Concept in Route target is very simple "export in VRF1 equal import in VRF2" and visa versa
- IMPORT-RT in ABC must not equal EXPORT RT in XYZ and visa versa
- IMPORT RT in (ABC,XYZ) must equal EXPORT RT in CENTRAL and visa versa IMPORT-RT in Central equal EXPORT-RT in (ABC,XYZ)
100% Correct Answer is A
Among the given options, A is the most correct one

100% Correct Answer is A
Router with VRF ABC --- Route Distinguisher: 65000:1 (default for vrf ABC)
 *> 2.2.2.2/32 0.0.0.0 0 32768 ?
ip vrf ABC rd 65000:1
 route-target export 65000:1111
 route-target export 65000:3333
 route-target import 65000:1111
 route-target import 65000:4444
Router with VRF XYZ ---- Route Distinguisher: 65000:2 (default for vrf XYZ)
 *> 3.3.3.3/32 0.0.0.0 0 32768 ?
ip vrf XYZ rd 65000:2
 route-target export 65000:2222
 route-target export 65000:3333
 route-target import 65000:2222
 route-target import 65000:4444
Router with VRF CENTRAL --- Route Distinguisher: 65000:3 (default for vrf CENTRAL)
 *>i 2.2.2.2/32 10.50.50.50 0 100 0 ?
 *>i 3.3.3.3/32 10.50.50.50 0 100 0 ?
ip vrf CENTRAL rd 65000:3
 route-target export 65000:4444
 route-target import 65000:3333
Before you comment.... everyone here knows "A" is the correct answer....
A is correct

comments.content: I am wrong it is A, I totally worked that backwards!

discussion.content:
I still think its B heres why:
Central VRF keeps it seperated by not communicating back to the same imports of ABC and XYZ.
Using that knowledge Answer A and Answer D is eliminated. C just doesnt make sense.
Should be A
Correct answer is A
I Agree, the anwer is "A"!
I disagree to all of you, correct answer is A

Agree that answer is A, that is the only configuration that achieves the desired effect.
Option B, VRF XYX Exports both 65000:1111 and 65000:2222, which means that VRF ABC imports RT 65000:1111, then it would receive VRF XYZ routes as well.

The sensor-group specifies a list of YANG models that are to be streamed. 
Sensor path: specifies the YANG path from which data has to be streamed.

choices.A: It is used to create a sensor-group and has a list of YANG models for streaming.
choices.D: It is used to identify traps for SNMP polling.
choices.B: It is used to create a subscription to specify the streaming interval.
choices.C: It is used to identify MIB entries and has a list of YANG models.

discussion.content:
Pag 5 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/aci/apic/sw/kb/b_KB_Configuring_Static_Management_Access.pdf
VLAN namespace is equivalent to a VLAN pool

Answer must be: A
-----
Create a VLAN namespace.

Example:
POST
https://apic-ip-address/api/mo/uni.xml

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!-- api/policymgr/mo/uni.xml -->
<polUni>
 <infraInfra>
 <!-- Static VLAN range -->
 <fvnsVlanInstP name="inband" allocMode="static">
 <fvnsEncapBlk name="encap" from="vlan-10" to="vlan-11"/>
 </fvnsVlanInstP>
 </infraInfra>
</polUni>

choices.A: to poll network devices on a 30-minute interval
choices.C: to subscribe to data that is streamed from a device
choices.D: to reset network devices that malfunction
